titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, Education, Media, Arts, and Culture (EMAC), Media, Arts, and Culture (MAC), Office Files of John P. Santos
A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, Education, Media, Arts, and Culture (EMAC), Media, Arts, and Culture (MAC), Office Files of John P. Santos FA540

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-10-25 18:28:00 -0400.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, Education, Media, Arts, and Culture (EMAC), Media, Arts, and Culture (MAC), Office Files of John P. Santos

physdesc.extent: About 24 LTR size Hollinger boxes, 3 LGL size Hollinger boxes, and 1 Half-LGL size Hollinger box

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Completion of a use agreement is required prior to providing scholarly access. See RAC Head of Reference (or applicable designee) for details. Ford Foundation holds title, copyright and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them. The Rockefeller Archive Center has authority to grant permission to cite and publish material from the collection for scholarly purposes. Permission to publish extensive excerpts, or material in its entirety, will be referred to the Ford Foundation.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Ford Foundation archive was deposited at the RAC in 2011. Ford Foundation records, correspondence, reports, program files and officers' papers were transferred to, and accessioned by the RAC, beginning in 2011. Accessions continue as necessary.

A second set of John P. Santos office files was transferred to the RAC by the Ford Foundation in 2018 and was ingested by the RAC as Accession 2018:063. This accession was incorporated into the collection during processing in October 2018.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

When requesting to view audiovisual material, please refer to the Title and the AV Number (example: AV 1916). Researchers are asked to check the "Restrictions" note for each Title. If a Title does not currently have an access copy, please contact a RAC archivist for further instruction.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Collection holds the office files of Ford Foundation Program Officer John Phillip Santos. The files were created during Santos' time in the Media, Arts, and Culture Unit (MAC) of the Education, Media, Arts, and Culture Program (EMAC).

Collection consists of only one series. It contains the subject and chronological files that Santos and his office created and maintained in order to document his management of Ford Foundation funds for various media related projects as well as his other administrative and program related activities.

Collection is comprised of more than one accession of John P. Santos office files ingested by the RAC over the years. The collection was expanded from 1.3 cubic feet to 10.77 cubic feet in 2018 when a second set of material was transferred, accessioned, and processed. The 2018 accession was added to the end of the original material in the same series in order to reconstitute the relationship between the two groups of records.

The collection principally consists of correspondence, reports, memos, agendas, press clippings, brochures, conference proceedings, Recommended Grant Action reports (RGAs), notes, drafts, and budgets. There is a small amount of audiovisual material within the collection. This material includes a few still images, a VHS tape, an audio CD, and an audio cassette.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The office files in the series appear to consist of two main types of records: subject files and chronological files. However, a Ford Foundation Archives inventory document found in one of the original collection boxes seemed to indicate a close relationship between some of the chronological files and some of the subject files. Within that box, subject files were listed as sub-files to the chronological files. Therefore, it was decided to keep the two types of records together within the series and amend the series title to account for both kinds of documents and the relationship between them.

Although there were some runs of alphabetically organized subject files within the original boxes, this type of scheme was not applied consistently or comprehensively to all of the subject files within the collection. No actions were taken to recapture or impose a total alphabetical arrangement of subject files during processing in 2018. Archivist deferred to the original order of the boxes and the material within the boxes.
The collection arrangement is as follows:

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Ford Foundation was chartered by Henry and Edsel Ford in 1936 "to receive and administer funds for scientific, educational and charitable purposes, all for the public welfare", and initially served the Ford family's charitable interests in the Detroit area. Following the deaths of Edsel Ford (1943) and Henry Ford (1947), the Foundation was propelled to the forefront of philanthropy as the largest American foundation in terms of both endowment and yearly expenditures, and with an international scope to its major program areas.

During the Foundation's first twenty years its major programs were in international economic development, primary and higher education, educational and public broadcasting, behavioral sciences, civil liberties, urban development, fine arts and the humanities. The Ford Foundation also partnered with the Rockefeller Foundation in supporting agricultural development in South America, Africa, and Southeast Asia. Since the 1970s, the Foundation has also pioneered programs in women's rights, energy policy, micro-financing in under-developed countries, establishing human rights groups, and improving international HIV/AIDS education.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: John Phillip Santos worked as a Program Officer in the Media, Arts, and Culture Unit (MAC) of the Ford Foundation's Education, Media, Arts, and Culture (EMAC) Program for six years between 1997 and 2002. In this position, he was responsible for grant making decisions regarding media production through the foundation's Media Projects Fund (MPF). He would review proposals for cultural and educational documentaries, films, media-centered festivals and events, and public broadcasting and television programs. He also focused on emerging technology for media.

Santos is a freelance filmmaker, producer, journalist, and author. Achievements he has made throughout his career include numerous documentaries and news programs he produced for CBS and PBS, articles published in newspapers like the San Antonio News-Express and the New York Times, and service on the President's Advisory Commission on Educational Excellence for Hispanic Americans. He became the first Mexican-American Rhodes Scholar in 1979.
Santos currently serves as a mentor at the Honors College of The University of Texas at San Antonio.

otherfindaid.head: Other Finding Aids
otherfindaid.p: Finding aids concerning the office files of other Ford Foundation officers in the Media, Arts, and Culture Unit include:

p.extref: FA1447 Ford Foundation records, Staff Subject Files, Jon Funabiki

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: A collection containing professional and personal materials created by John Phillip Santos is held at the University of Texas at San Antonio Libraries Special Collections. Some files in the collection specifically regard Santos' work with the Ford Foundation:
John Phillip Santos Papers, MS 203, University of Texas at San Antonio Libraries Special Collections

physdesc.extent: About 24 LTR size Hollinger boxes, 3 LGL size Hollinger boxes, and 1 Half-LGL size Hollinger box

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series holds the subject and chronological files that John Phillip Santos created during his time as Program Officer in the Media, Arts, and Culture Unit (MAC) of the Ford Foundation's Education, Media, Arts, and Culture Program (EMAC). It consists of more than one accession of Santos' records. The set of records belonging to the first accession of material remains at the beginning of the collection and extends from El Movimiento, 1991, Box 1, Folder 1 to Program Associate - Giraud, Christine, 2000-2001, Box 3, Folder 25. All remaining records in the series originate from the later accession of materials processed in 2018.

The original accession of records formed an incomplete set of subject files that encouraged the addition of the later accession into the series as a way to repopulate an evident gap in content and reconstitute a relationship between contextually linked documents. The later accession of records revealed a connection between the subject files Santos created and the chronological files he largely used to document his negative responses to proposals for grant funding. Series description was expanded to properly document the association between subject and chronological file.

Subject files in the series largely regard various media projects and initiatives that the Ford Foundation supported through its Media Projects Fund (MPF) as well as administrative and program planning activities of the Media, Arts, and Culture Unit (MAC) and its parent Education, Media, Arts, and Culture Program (EMAC). Prominent topics and themes with which Santos dealt in his position as Program Officer for MAC between 1997 and 2002 include the digital transition of public television, education and training for overcoming potential inequalities generated by a digital divide, public support for public television, questions about the role of public television, growing concerns about the integrity of news reporting, and representation of minorities, specifically Latino Americans, within entertainment and news media. Santos appears to have used the term "convenings" to refer to meetings organized at the Ford Foundation for different groups of arts, media, and entertainment professionals such as independent filmmakers and public broadcast grantees. He also created files to document the work of specific Ford Foundation consultants and program associates who assisted his work.

did.unittitle: Minority Voices in China's Dayao Mountain District

did.physdesc: File includes a set of images. The images have been attached to two sheets of paper. The pictures depict an educational street play and other activities organized by Nalamdana.

did.unittitle: Nalamdana Promo / Azhage - Song on HIV/AIDS / Aaadimatham- telefilm on HIV/AIDS

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Three production on HIV/AIDS: Nalamdana Promo - 7 minutes, English; Azhagig - Song on HIV/AIDS - 4 minutes, Tamil; Aadimatham - Telefilm on HIV/AIDS, 24 minutes, Tamil.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: File contains a group of records that may have belonged to a different file at one point or that may have been intended to be placed in a different file. These records regard a collaboration between the Center for Media and Learning (CML)/American Social History Project (ASHP) at City University of New York (CUNY) and Clarity Film Productions.
